IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDescription: Serving the community through provision of healthcare and health/safety education.
IRS990.MissionDescription: We serve together to heal body, mind and spirit, to improve the health of our community, and to be good stewards of the resources entrusted to us.
IRS990.Description: Hegg Memorial Health Center's (HMHC) purpose is to provide acute inpatient and outpatient services as well as residential nursing home services. The amount of care provided was 640 acute inpatient days of care, 73 births, 21,638 nursing home days of care, 32,412 outpatient visits which include 8,334 home health visits, and 17,853 clinic visits.HMHC received the Summit Award from Press Ganey for achieving a patient satisfaction score of greater than the 90th percentile for 3 consecutive years in the Emergency Department.The Whispering Heights Nursing Home has added a golf cart and trailer to provide rides for the residents. The trailer has added much excitement and life to the lives of the residents. Residents enjoyed rides in the spring time, feeling the fresh air on their faces and watching the planting of crops and the budding flowers and trees. In the summer, residents enjoyed riding through the trails and observing the colors of flowers and trees and watching the river go up and down due to all the rain. Residents made friends with three little goats who would run to the fence when they saw the cart and trailer coming down the road to bring them treats. The cart also took residents to the campground for picnics this year with the trailer. Residents enjoyed many sights and sounds while riding in the trailer and will miss it over the winter months. The residents used the trailer until late October to get out and enjoy the fresh air.The goal of the Community Education Department of HMHC is to offer a resource for medical issues as well as wellness promotion. The Community Education Department offers many opportunities for the community to grow in their knowledge of medical concerns and wellness matters. The Community Education Department covers all ages of the community. Physicians and nurses presented educational opportunities for the 5th graders (both boys and girls) in Rock Valley and surrounding areas. Babysitting classes were offered in May to 60 youth of the community. The Community Education Department also provides a program called HANK (Healthy Active Nutritious Kids) that served over 900 kids in grades K-5 in Rock Valley and the surrounding areas. The program focused on nutrition, exercise, and parent involvement in their overall health. Project Truth is an annual program for 6th-8th graders that focuses on topics that can negatively affect the youth of the community such as alcohol abuse, drug abuse, and sexual purity issues. Students were also educated on way to either abstain or quit smoking. Lunch-N-Learns that focused on health and wellness topics were offered to adults in the community. Programs for diabetics and wellness screens to check for health issues are offered at a low cost to the community. Many other events touch on teaching the basics of certain health related issues that the community may have to learn more about the health issue and how to deal or correct them. HMHC also promotes health in the community by holding many events in the community for anyone to participate in. Whether it is by staying physically active and being involved in our exercise programs/events such as our 5k/10k Run/Walk or in programs held for the obese and/or those with health issues. In November a Women's Night out was offered to 250 women to encourage humor in yourself and in life. A community breakfast was offered to all area employers and managers to learn more about Stress Management, approximately 200 area individuals attended and enjoyed this morning meeting. A celebration for breast cancer survivors was held to celebrate their achievement in overcoming this disease. A supper was served and a breast health physician was available to answer any medical questions. A Depression and Anxiety evening event included a licensed counselor giving tips on combating depression and anxiety. Over 50 people participated in the event.Various employees are involved in the promotion of the American Cancer Society Relay for Life, the American Heart Association Heart Walk, Alzheimer's Association walk, Memory Loss Support Group, and free Prenatal Classes. CPR and First Aid Classes are offered to health care workers, daycare providers, foster/adoptive parents, and the general public at a reduced cost.Various organizations request speakers from the Hegg Community Education Department. The speakers are provided at no cost utilizing the professional knowledge of our Health Center.The Community Education Department strives to continue offering a wide array of services at a free or reduced rate. The goal of the department is to further the mission of the Health Center through caring for others, body, mind, and soul.

OtherSecurities.Description: Interest in Net Assets of Avera Health Foundation

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: Residents or Resident's family members deposit money into an account that HMHC manages. The residents can use the deposited funds for small personal expenses that arise such as salon visits, personal items, and etc.

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.ReturnReference: Description of Uncertain Tax Positions Under FIN 48:
Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: The Center has adopted the provisions of FASB Accounting Standards Codification Topic ASC 740-10 (previously Financial Interpretation No. 48, Accounting for Uncertainty in Income Taxes), on January 1, 2009. The implementation of this standard had no impact on the financial statements. As of both the date of adoption, and as of December 31, 2009, the unrecognized tax benefit accrual was zero. The Center will recognize future accrued interest and penalties related to unrecognized tax benefits in income tax expense if incurred. The Organization is no longer subject to Federal tax examinations by tax authorities for years before 2007.

Form990ScheduleHPartVI.IncomeBasedCriteria: Part I, Line 3c: Hegg Memorial Health Center (HMHC) utilizes the FPG as a starting point to determine if the patients meet or qualify for charity care. If the patient's income is above the FPG, they are issued points depending on how much they are over the FPG. Patients are also issued points for dollar value of major assets. Points are then deducted based on the dollar amount of medical bills a patient owes. From there, the total points are calculated and used to determine the percentage of financial assistance that gets deducted from the patient's medical bill within our health center. If a patient falls below the FPG, it generates a 100% write-off under the charity care policy.
Form990ScheduleHPartVI.CostingMethodUsed: Part I, Line 7: Lines 7a, 7b and 7c were determined using the ratio of patient care costs to charges calculated by HMHC's general ledger accounting system. Lines 7e, 7f and 7i were obtained utilizing the actual general ledger system. Line 7g was obtained from the Medicare cost report.
Form990ScheduleHPartVI.PercentOfTotalExpenseExpln: Part I, Line 7f: Bad debt expense of $124,655 was subtracted from total operating expense.
Form990ScheduleHPartVI.BadDebtFootnote: Part III, Line 4: A) The cost to charge ratio was calculated by HMHC's general ledger accounting system. B) Bad debt write-offs are recorded using gross charges. If an account is written off to bad debts, payments received after the write off for that account are posted to the Allowance for Bad Debt Account. No discounts are applied to the bad debt allowance or expense as the accounts are not eligible for discounts once they reach the point of being deemed uncollectible. The Allowance for Bad Debt is calculated using an estimated uncollectible percentage on Accounts Receivable. The difference between the estimate and the amount recorded to the Allowance for Bad Debt is recorded to Bad Debt Expense.C) All accounts are considered at charge value as opposed to cost value. HMHC estimates that approximately 25% of bad debt expense at cost could reasonably be attributable to patients who likely would qualify for financial assistance under the hospital's financial assistance policy if sufficient information had been available to the facility to make a determination of their eligibility. D) Footnote From Financial Statement: The carrying amount of patient and resident receivables is reduced by a valuation allowance that reflects management's best estimate of amounts that will not be collected from patients, residents and third-party payors. Management reviews patient and resident receivables by payor class and applies percentages to determine estimated amounts that will not be collected from third parties under contractual agreements and amounts that will not be collected from patients and residents due to bad debts. Management considers historical write off and recovery information in determining the estimated bad debt provision. Management also reviews accounts to determine if classification as charity care is appropriate.
Form990ScheduleHPartVI.ShortfallAsCommunityBenefit: Part III, Line 8: Medicare allowable cost of care was calculated from the Medicare cost report for fiscal year ending 6/30/2010.
Form990ScheduleHPartVI.NeedsAssessment: Part VI, Line 2: The majority of HMHC's community benefit stems from our Community Education Department. The manager of that department also oversees Clinic nursing, Employee Health for our organization, and Occupational Health. By being involved and hearing patients' needs from the clinic, employee needs through Employee Health, and business needs through Occupational Health, the manager has a great understanding of what is needed in the community. The Community Benefit team also conducts surveys at community events to get a better understanding of the needs and wants of the community.
Form990ScheduleHPartVI.PatientEducationAssistance: Part VI, Line 3: HMHC contacts the patient regarding payment concerns (unless the organization is contacted by the patient prior to) regarding being able to make required payments. Payment options, financial assistance and governmental benefits are discussed with the patient by phone, mail, or in person. A financial assistance policy and application forms are mailed out (upon request), picked up by the patient, or available online. HMHC discusses the availability of various government benefits, such as Medicaid or state programs with the patient, and assists the patient with qualification for such programs, where applicable.
Form990ScheduleHPartVI.CommunityInformation: Part VI, Line 4: Rock Valley is a rural community located in Sioux County, Iowa. Agriculture and manufacturing are popular in this community. In 2005, Rock Valley recorded a population of 2,816. Rock Valley continues to grow both in population and in businesses. In 2000, the median household income for Rock Valley was recorded at $36,967 with 15 families (or 1.9% of the population) being reported as below the poverty level. Hegg Memorial Health Center is 1 of 4 hospitals located in Sioux County.
Form990ScheduleHPartVI.CommunityBuildingActivities: Part VI, Line 5: HMHC feels that the health and wellness of their service area/community are of utmost importance. As the largest healthcare leader in the community, HMHC is a centralized resource that not only provides compassionate patient care, but also offers life skills classes and health care reform education and webinar for the community. HMHC is also involved with the area Economic Development Board, Chamber of Commerce, and the Sioux County Coalition. HMHC work to enhance the quality of life and empower its patients, care-givers and community with the resources they need when they need them. Part VI, Line 8: Hegg Memorial Health Center's community benefits are reported with Avera McKennan in the state of South Dakota due to their affiliation. HMHC also reports to the Iowa Hospital Association (IHA) for the state's reporting on community benefits, and files their own community benefit report within the organization. For fiscal year 2010, the community benefit report will be published in the local newspaper and on the website.
Form990ScheduleHPartVI.OtherInformation: Part VI, Line 6: HMHC has a nine member board comprised of citizens that occupy the primary service area. HMHC extends privileges to physicians in the immediate area. HMHC uses surplus funds to fund building improvements to enhance services to our patients. The facility recently added on to the long term care facility, did some minor remodeling work in the hospital, and is exploring opportunities for construction of a rehab wellness facility.

Form990ScheduleIPartIV.Identifier: Procedure for Monitoring Grants in the U.S.:
Form990ScheduleIPartIV.Explanation: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2: The CEO and Marketing Director review new and recurring (annual) sponsorship and donation requests as they arise. Determinations are made based on multiple criteria including HMHC's budget, the requesting organization's goal/mission, location, and other factors.

Form990ScheduleJPartIII.Explanation: Club dues such as Rotary Club and Kiwanis Club as well as local Chamber Committees.

The policy is not written; however, a formal policy is being drafted. Hegg Memorial Health Center knows that being one of the largest organizations in the community they need to give back to the community and make their presence known throughout by involvement in civic organizations and social clubs.
Glenn Zevenbergen, CEO, received $5,467 toward his CAA (Cash Accumulation Account); however, this plan was terminated by calendar year 2010.
Schedule J, Part II: Glenn Zevenbergen, CEO, is compensated by Avera McKennan, 800 East 21st Street, Sioux Falls, SD 57101.

Form990ScheduleLPartIV.Relationship: Family Member of Korrie VanMaanen, Board Member

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, line 3
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The hospital has a management agreement with Avera Health in which services of the CEO are paid through Avera Health. Additionally, the hospital contracts with Avera Health for services of the clinic manager, four physicians, one Physicians Assistant, and one surgeon.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, line 6
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The organization has stockholder memberships. Persons must be a stockholder in order to be voted onto the governing board.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, line 7a
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: All stockholders have the same voting rights. Stockholders can vote at the annual meeting or through absentee ballot.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, line 7b
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Retiring board members nominate two candidates for his/her vacant position, candidates are subject to approval by the full Board of Directors, and the membership may nominate not more than two candidates for each vacancy on the Board of Directors. The voting shall be by ballot and the elected director must receive a plurality of the votes of the members either present at the annual meeting or who have voted through absentee ballot. Write in candidates shall be allowed on the absentee ballots. If an elected director cannot complete his or her term of office, the total Board of Directors shall have the power to fill or not fill the vacancy created.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, line 8b
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The committees bring recommendations to the board; the full board votes on recommendations. Committees don't have full authority to act on behalf of the board.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 11
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The CEO will review the 990 in detail. Upon completion of the review, the 990 is provided to each board member. The CEO presents the 990 to the Board of Directors at the meeting held prior to its filing if so requested by any board member. Whether presented in a board meeting or not, the 990 is not filed until each board member has been given a copy of it and given ample time to review it.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 12c
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: A statement is given to board members, the CEO, and the CFO, asking for any potential issues that could give rise to a conflict. Said persons are required to disclose any conflicts and sign off on the statement annually. The Board determines and reviews any possible conflict of interests that may arise. If any conflicts arise, the affected person(s) must refrain from discussion and voting on anything dealing with the item causing conflict.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 15
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: CEO - The regional manager at Avera Health evaluates the CEO and meets with the Board of Directors from the Hospital. He recommends a salary adjustment for the CEO. The Board of Directors is responsible for approval of the salary adjustment. The regional manager uses policies and procedures as set forth by Avera Health. CFO - The human resources director uses the IHA survey from the previous year to determine a minimum and maximum range for market salary adjustments. A recommendation is made to the Board. Merit increases are determined through a review process.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, line 19
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Documents are available upon request with the approval of the Board.
